title: How to Make Glazed Lemon Poke Cake

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).
Lightly grease and flour a 10-inch Bundt pan.
steps.description: You can use butter or a cooking spray.

steps.headline: In a large bowl, cream butter and sugar with an electric mixer until fluffy
Beat in the lemon juice, zest, and egg yolks (one yolk at a time).
In a separate bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, and salt.
Stir the dry ingredients into the butter mixture alternately with buttermilk.
steps.description: This means to start and end with dry ingredients–3 additions of dry; 2 of buttermilk. Set aside, again.

steps.headline: In another large bowl, beat egg whites to the stiff peaks stage.
steps.description: If you can flip over the bowl without the contents moving or spilling, you've beaten it enough.

steps.headline: Measure 1/3 of the whites and stir into the batter.
Fold in the remaining egg whites until, being careful not to overdo it.
Pour the batter into the Bundt pan.
Bake for 50 to 55 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean.
Let cool in the pan for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Remove from pan and transfer to a wire rack.

steps.headline: In a small saucepan, combine sugar, water, and lemon zest and bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally.
Boil for 1 minute without stirring.
With the heat turned off, carefully remove the lemon zest and stir in lemon juice.
Whisk together icing sugar and lemon juice until smooth in a medium bowl.
Add melted butter and whisk until a thick but pourable glaze forms.
Poke holes on the top of the cake with a skewer.
steps.description: The holes should almost, but not completely, penetrate the cake. This is where the "poke" in the dessert name comes from.

steps.headline: Brush the syrup all over the top and let cool completely.
Spoon the glaze over the cake.
Let stand for 15 minutes until the cake sets.

text: Baking the Cake Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).  Lightly grease and flour a 10-inch Bundt pan. You can use butter or a cooking spray. In a large bowl, cream butter and sugar with an electric mixer until fluffy  Beat in the lemon juice, zest, and egg yolks (one yolk at a time). Set aside. In a separate bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, and salt.  Stir the dry ingredients into the butter mixture alternately with buttermilk. This means to start and end with dry ingredients–3 additions of dry; 2 of buttermilk. Set aside, again. In another large bowl, beat egg whites to the stiff peaks stage. If you can flip over the bowl without the contents moving or spilling, you've beaten it enough. Measure 1/3 of the whites and stir into the batter.  Fold in the remaining egg whites until, being careful not to overdo it.  Pour the batter into the Bundt pan.  Bake for 50 to 55 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean.  Let cool in the pan for 10 minutes. Remove from pan and transfer to a wire rack. Making the Lemon Syrup In a small saucepan, combine sugar, water, and lemon zest and bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally.  Boil for 1 minute without stirring.  With the heat turned off, carefully remove the lemon zest and stir in lemon juice.  Making the Lemon Glaze Whisk together icing sugar and lemon juice until smooth in a medium bowl.  Add melted butter and whisk until a thick but pourable glaze forms.  Serving the Cake Poke holes on the top of the cake with a skewer. The holes should almost, but not completely, penetrate the cake. This is where the "poke" in the dessert name comes from. Brush the syrup all over the top and let cool completely.  Spoon the glaze over the cake.  Let stand for 15 minutes until the cake sets.
